Title: No acceleration of recovery from exercise-induced muscle damage after cold or hot water immersion in women: A randomised controlled trial.
summary: In this study of young women, cold water immersion after intense exercise did not help muscles recover any faster than hot water immersion or no intervention. While cold and hot water affected body temperature and muscle oxygenation differently, neither method sped up recovery or reduced muscle soreness.

Title: Effects of cold-water immersion on energy expenditure, ad-libitum energy intake and appetite in healthy adults.
summary: This study found that people tend to eat more after immersing themselves in cold water, compared to warmer water or just sitting in a warm room. That means while cold water immersion is popular, it could lead to unwanted increases in food intake, which is important for anyone trying to watch their weight.

Title: Effect of cold-water immersion treatment on recovery from exercise-induced muscle damage in the hamstring.
summary: This research found that five days of cold-water immersion after tough hamstring exercise helped women recover faster, with less soreness and better muscle function than resting alone. It suggests cold-water baths may boost muscle recovery for active women.

Title: Acute moderate normobaric hypoxia does not modify circulating thyroid hormone concentrations induced by 1 h of head-out cold-water immersion.
summary: Researchers found that one hour of head-out cold water immersion triggered a drop in body temperature and changes in thyroid hormones (which help regulate metabolism), but doing this under low-oxygen conditions didn't make any further difference. This suggests that simply immersing in cold water, not combining it with hypoxia, influences thyroid-related responses.

Title: Short-duration cold exposure decreases fasting-induced glucose intolerance but has no effect on resting energy expenditure.
summary: Brief cold water immersion, performed during a fasting period, helped improve blood sugar control and insulin sensitivity in young women, but did not make a difference in how much energy their bodies used at rest. This suggests possible metabolic benefits for women when fasting, though more research is needed on other groups.

Title: Short-term effects of two different recovery strategies on muscle contractile properties in healthy active men: A randomised cross-over study.
summary: This study compared cold water immersion, hot water immersion, and passive rest for muscle recovery after exercise in active men. The results suggest that cold water immersion does not offer unique benefits over other strategies, which matters when choosing methods for muscle recovery.

Title: Massage enhances recovery following exercise-induced muscle damage in older adults.
summary: For older adults recovering from strenuous exercise, cold water immersion gave a little relief for muscle soreness but didn't meaningfully help with regaining strength or balance. This suggests cold water baths might not offer much advantage for most aspects of exercise recovery in this group.

Title: Thermo-therapy and cryotherapy to decrease the symptoms of restless leg syndrome during the pregnancy: A randomized clinical trial.
Demographic: Pregnant women with restless legs syndrome
summary: This clinical trial showed that immersing the legs in cold water was more effective than warm water at easing restless legs syndrome symptoms in pregnant women, suggesting a simple and accessible option for symptom relief.

Title: The physiological effects of daily cold-water immersion on 5-day tournament performance in international standard youth field-hockey players.
Demographic: elite youth field-hockey players (German under-18 national squad)
summary: This research looked at whether daily cold-water immersion after exercise helped elite youth field hockey players during a demanding tournament. It found that the cold baths did not provide any advantages for performance, muscle soreness, or recovery compared to just resting.

Title: Partial-body cryotherapy (-135°C) and cold-water immersion (10°C) after muscle damage in females.
summary: Cold water immersion helped women feel less muscle soreness after tough exercise, but didn't speed up muscle recovery or reduce swelling. This suggests it's good for easing discomfort, but not for boosting performance or healing.

Title: Cold-Water Immersion Does Not Accelerate Performance Recovery After 10-km Street Run: Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial.
summary: After running 10 kilometers, male recreational runners didn't recover faster with cold water immersion compared to just resting or simply sitting in room temperature water. This suggests that, for muscle recovery after this type of run, cold water immersion doesn't provide extra benefits.

Title: Comparative efficacy of active recovery and cold water immersion as post-match recovery interventions in elite youth soccer.
summary: Elite youth soccer players who used cold water immersion after games recovered faster—with less muscle damage and soreness—compared to those who only stretched. Cold water baths were about as effective as active recovery techniques for speeding up muscle recovery.

Title: Cold water submersion attenuates post-submersion aerobic performance and orthostatic tolerance irrespective of partial rehydration with water.
summary: This study found that after four hours in cold water, healthy men had lower exercise endurance and poorer tolerance to standing upright. Drinking water after the immersion didn't help. These results suggest long cold-water exposure might reduce physical performance and blood pressure stability afterward.

Title: Faster physical performance recovery with cold water immersion is not related to lower muscle damage level in professional soccer players.
summary: For professional soccer players, using cold water immersion after intense exercise helped speed up recovery of performance and reduced muscle soreness, even though it wasn't directly tied to lower muscle damage. This suggests cold water immersion could be a useful recovery tool for athletes.

Title: Effects of Chronic Cold-Water Immersion in Elite Rugby Players
summary: In elite male rugby players, using cold-water immersion after training may help reduce muscle soreness and feelings of fatigue over a stressful three-week period, suggesting it can benefit recovery in demanding sports situations.

Title: Immersion with menthol improves recovery between 2 cycling exercises in hot and humid environment.
summary: This study tested whether cold water immersion (CWI), with or without menthol, helped cyclists recover in hot conditions. Standard CWI alone didn’t improve recovery or performance, while adding menthol did help performance but might impair the body’s ability to regulate core temperature. For basic cold water immersion, no clear benefit was found.

Title: Cold-water or partial-body cryotherapy? Comparison of physiological responses and recovery following muscle damage.
summary: The study compared cold-water immersion and partial-body cryotherapy in healthy men after muscle-damaging exercise. Despite differences in how each method affected body responses right after treatment, both approaches led to similar recovery, with no real advantage for one over the other.

Title: Recovery following a marathon: a comparison of cold water immersion, whole body cryotherapy and a placebo control.
Demographic: endurance trained males who completed a marathon
summary: This study compared cold water immersion, whole body cryotherapy, and a placebo on recovery in male marathon runners. It found that cold-based recovery techniques didn't actually help muscle recovery or reduce soreness compared to a placebo, which suggests much of the benefit may simply come from believing the treatment works.

Title: Effect of Cold-Water Immersion on Elbow Flexors Muscle Thickness After Resistance Training
summary: This study found that cold water immersion after lifting weights can help reduce muscle swelling in men, potentially helping muscles recover faster. If you want to limit swelling after tough workouts, CWI might offer some benefits.

Title: Physiological and Perceived Effects of Forearm or Head Cooling During Simulated Firefighting Activity and Rehabilitation.
summary: Water-based forearm cooling was helpful for firefighters during recovery breaks, lowering core body temperature and physical strain. However, head cooling didn't provide any measured benefit, highlighting that not all cooling strategies work equally well for physically demanding jobs.

Title: Tarp-Assisted Cooling as a Method of Whole-Body Cooling in Hyperthermic Individuals.
Demographic: hyperthermic individuals following exercise (likely healthy adults; sex breakdown analyzed but not explicitly stated)
summary: This study shows that tarp-assisted cold water cooling can quickly lower body temperature in overheated individuals and may be especially useful when traditional cold water immersion isn't available, making it valuable for emergency response and public health.

Title: Postexercise cold-water immersion improves intermittent high-intensity exercise performance in normothermia.
summary: Taking a short cold-water bath after exercise helped young men perform better in a tough, team sport-style workout, making the exercise feel easier and less taxing on the body.

Title: Use of Cold-Water Immersion to Reduce Muscle Damage and Delayed-Onset Muscle Soreness and Preserve Muscle Power in Jiu-Jitsu Athletes.
summary: For highly trained male jiu-jitsu athletes, cold water immersion after intense training led to quicker muscle recovery, less soreness, and lower signs of muscle damage compared to just resting. This suggests athletes might benefit from adding cold water immersion to their recovery routines.

Title: Dosages of cold-water immersion post exercise on functional and clinical responses: a randomized controlled trial.
summary: This study found that cold water immersion speeds up recovery from muscle soreness and helps restore strength after exercise in healthy men, with no indication of negative side effects. It suggests cold water baths could be an effective strategy for active individuals looking to recover faster.

Title: Cold Water Immersion is Acutely Detrimental but Increases Performance Post-12 h in Rugby Players.
summary: For male rugby players, cold water immersion after exercise temporarily reduced performance but helped them recover better and perform more jumps 12 hours later. This suggests that while it may not help immediately, it could be a useful recovery tool between matches or intense training sessions.

Title: Physiologic and Perceptual Responses to Cold-Shower Cooling After Exercise-Induced Hyperthermia.
Demographic: Healthy young adults (19-35 years) exposed to exercise-induced hyperthermia
summary: After hot exercise, a cold shower helped people cool down faster and feel more comfortable than just resting. While not as effective as some other cooling methods, a cold shower can be useful when better options aren’t available.

Title: The Beneficial Effect of Parasympathetic Reactivation on Sympathetic Drive During Simulated Rugby Sevens.
summary: Ten male rugby athletes recovered after intense play using either cold water immersion or a passive method. Cold water immersion improved their heart's ability to relax after matches, even though it did not affect sprint performance. This could be important for sports recovery.

Title: Acute effects of Finnish sauna and cold-water immersion on haemodynamic variables and autonomic nervous system activity in patients with heart failure.
Demographic: patients with chronic heart failure, patients with coronary artery disease, and healthy controls; all male; mean age ~61 years
summary: This study explored whether cold-water immersion is safe for men with heart failure, finding that it caused some changes in heart and blood pressure, but no dangerous reactions. It suggests cold exposure is generally tolerated by this group, though results can't be applied to women.

Title: Effects of cold water immersion and active recovery on hemodynamics and recovery of muscle strength following resistance exercise.
summary: This study explored how cold water immersion after weight-lifting exercises affected blood flow and muscle strength in men. Researchers found that cold water immersion didn't offer any real benefit—or harm—when it came to muscle strength recovery compared to resting or gentle cycling. This suggests that using cold water for recovery may not improve strength after resistance exercise.

Title: Effectiveness of cold water immersion for treating exertional heat stress when immediate response is not possible.
summary: Researchers found that even if cold water immersion therapy is delayed for up to 40 minutes after severe heat stress, it remains a very effective way to rapidly cool the body. This highlights the method as the best available emergency treatment for exertional heatstroke.

Title: Postexercise cold water immersion benefits are not greater than the placebo effect.
summary: After intense exercise, cold water immersion was not better than a placebo in helping with muscle recovery, pain relief, or boosting energy. This means the positive effects people feel may be due to their expectations, rather than any unique physical benefit from the cold water itself.

Title: Comparison of the effects of electrical stimulation and cold-water immersion on muscle soreness after resistance exercise.
summary: This study checked whether cold-water immersion after weight training helps muscle recovery compared to electrical stimulation or doing nothing special. The results suggest that cold-water immersion may help muscles recover more quickly, though it also raised some inflammation markers. Although it didn't boost exercise performance versus other methods, it might help reduce muscle damage in young men after heavy lifting.

Title: Effect of recovery interventions on cycling performance and pacing strategy in the heat.
summary: After intense cycling in the heat, cold water immersion as a recovery method didn't improve overall time-trial performance compared to other recovery strategies, but it did help riders keep a steadier pace. This suggests cold water immersion might affect how athletes cope with heat during exercise recovery, though it didn't offer a direct performance boost.

Title: Influence of contrast shower and water immersion on recovery in elite netballers.
summary: Elite female netball players didn’t recover physically faster after cold water immersion, but felt better about their recovery compared to just resting. While this method won’t boost actual recovery, it might help athletes feel more refreshed or ready for their next game.

Title: Does hydrotherapy help or hinder adaptation to training in competitive cyclists?
summary: This study looked at whether cold water immersion helps or hinders cycling performance after intense training. The results showed no evidence that cold water immersion harms performance, with some small signs it may help with sprint power. Overall, the technique was neither clearly beneficial nor harmful for competitive male cyclists.

Title: Recovery from repeated on-court tennis sessions: combining cold-water immersion, compression, and sleep recovery interventions.
summary: After tough tennis sessions, combining cold water immersion with compression garments and good sleep habits helped athletes recover faster. They could keep playing longer, jump higher, and felt less sore, all without negative side effects.

Title: Effects of whole body cryotherapy and cold water immersion on knee skin temperature.
summary: This study compared two cold therapies—whole body cryotherapy and cold water immersion—to see how well they cooled the skin around the knee in healthy men. Both treatments lowered skin temperature, but neither got cold enough to provide pain-relieving effects, suggesting limited usefulness for immediate analgesia.

Title: Cold-water immersion decreases cerebral oxygenation but improves recovery after intermittent-sprint exercise in the heat.
Demographic: unspecified athletes or physically active adults
summary: After intense sprints in hot conditions, cooling off in cold water helped people regain muscle strength and reduced signs of muscle damage and inflammation, even though it slightly lowered brain oxygen levels. These results suggest that cold-water immersion is an effective recovery tool for people exercising in the heat.

Title: Effect of evening postexercise cold water immersion on subsequent sleep.
summary: This study looked at whether cold water immersion after working out in the evening helps people sleep better. There was no difference in any sleep measures, meaning cold water immersion didn’t improve or harm sleep for these trained male cyclists.

Title: Individual perception of recovery is related to subsequent sprint performance.
summary: This study showed that male rugby players who used cold water immersion after intense training felt better recovered and performed faster in sprints the next day, hinting that both body and mind responses to cold water help boost athletic recovery.

Title: Association between post-game recovery protocols, physical and perceived recovery, and performance in elite Australian Football League players.
Demographic: elite Australian Football League players (male athletes)
summary: Elite football players who chose cold-water immersion and other recovery strategies felt more recovered after games, but this didn't lead to better physical recovery or improved performance on the field. For athletes, cold-water immersion may help you feel better, but it doesn't necessarily enhance your physical recovery or game results.

Title: Heat production and heat loss responses to cold water immersion after 35 days horizontal bed rest.
Demographic: subjects after 35 days of horizontal bed rest
summary: After 35 days of bed rest, participants experienced muscle loss, but their body's ability to produce or lose heat in cold water did not change. This suggests leg muscle atrophy doesn’t affect how people respond to cold water immersion.

Title: Effect of daily cold water immersion on heart rate variability and subjective ratings of well-being in highly trained swimmers.
summary: Daily cold water immersion after training sessions helped competitive swimmers recover by supporting their heart's relaxation response and improving how well they slept. This suggests that cold water baths could be useful for athletes looking to recover better during intense training weeks.

Title: Cutaneous vascular and core temperature responses to sustained cold exposure in hypoxia.
summary: Researchers looked at how breathing low-oxygen air (hypoxia) affects skin blood flow and body temperature during cold water immersion. They found that being in hypoxia led to more blood vessel tightening in the skin, but it didn't make people cool down any faster at their core. This suggests that oxygen levels don't have much impact on core temperature loss during cold water exposure.

Title: Effects of age and spa treatment on match running performance over two consecutive games in highly trained young soccer players.
Demographic: highly trained young male soccer players
summary: Younger and older boys played two soccer matches in close succession. For the older boys, a spa treatment including cold water immersion helped them recover and run faster in the second game, suggesting this combination of treatments could speed up recovery for youth athletes.

Title: Effects of cold water immersion on the recovery of physical performance and muscle damage following a one-off soccer match.
summary: After a competitive soccer match, players who used cold water immersion had less muscle damage and soreness and recovered their strength faster than those who used warm water. This suggests that cold water immersion can help male athletes recover more quickly after intense physical activity.

Title: Comparison between cold water immersion therapy (CWIT) and light emitting diode therapy (LEDT) in short-term skeletal muscle recovery after high-intensity exercise in athletes--preliminary results.
summary: This research tested cold water immersion against light therapy for muscle recovery in young male athletes. Cold water immersion didn't show clear benefits for speeding up recovery after intense exercise, and the other tested therapy performed better.

Title: The impact of cold-water immersion on power production in the vertical jump and the benefits of a dynamic exercise warm-up.
Demographic: physically active men, current or ex-NCAA Division 1 athletes
summary: Cold water immersion before athletic activity can decrease physical performance—in this case, lower body power in a vertical jump—unless a dynamic warm-up is performed afterward. This highlights the importance of proper preparation when training or competing in the cold.

Title: Cold-water immersion and the treatment of hyperthermia: using 38.6°C as a safe rectal temperature cooling limit.
Demographic: Young adults (6 men and 4 women), healthy, physically active (mean VO2max 59.3 mL·kg(-1)·min(-1))
summary: This study explored how to safely use very cold water immersion for people with dangerously high body temperatures from heat stroke. By stopping cooling when the core temperature reached 38.6°C, the risk of cooling the body too much was avoided, providing guidance to safely treat overheating in emergency situations.

Title: Effect of cold water immersion on 100-m sprint performance in well-trained swimmers.
summary: Well-trained swimmers who used cold water immersion after sprinting felt more recovered, but actually swam more slowly afterward compared to when they used passive recovery. The main takeaway is that cold water immersion didn't improve performance and may even slow athletes down, even if they feel better subjectively.

Title: The effects of recovery interventions on consecutive days of intermittent sprint exercise.
summary: This study explored whether cold water immersion and other recovery strategies help maintain performance after hard training in female netball players. No recovery method, including cold water immersion, provided a meaningful advantage for physical performance after 24 hours.

Title: Effects of four recovery methods on repeated maximal rock climbing performance.
summary: Cold water immersion helped female climbers maintain their performance during repeated efforts, suggesting it can be an effective recovery tool to support endurance and reduce fatigue.

Title: A single 10-min bout of cold-water immersion therapy after strenuous plyometric exercise has no beneficial effect on recovery from the symptoms of exercise-induced muscle damage.
summary: This study found that a single 10-minute session of cold water immersion after intense jumping exercise didn't help young women recover from muscle soreness or damage any faster. While cold therapy is often used for recovery, this research suggests it may not be effective in some situations.

Title: Effect of stress on pain perception in young women.
summary: This study looked at college-aged women and found that cold water immersion is particularly effective at making people less sensitive to pain. Knowing that cold exposure can raise pain tolerance could be useful for non-drug pain management, especially for women.

Title: Effect on sport hemolysis of cold water leg immersion in athletes after training sessions.
summary: In elite rugby players, immersing the legs in cold water after heavy training prevented certain blood cell changes linked to exercise. This hints that cold water immersion could help athletes recover better by protecting their red blood cells.

Title: Effect of water immersion methods on post-exercise recovery from simulated team sport exercise.
summary: This study found that cold water immersion is a particularly effective way for male athletes to recover after intense team sports. It led to less muscle soreness and quicker performance recovery, which could be helpful for anyone looking to bounce back faster after hard exercise.

Title: Cognitive, psychomotor, and physical performance in cold air after cooling by exercise in cold water.
summary: After cold water immersion, men's thinking skills stayed the same even with mild body cooling, but some physical abilities, like a step test, were reduced. This suggests that while your body might get colder, your mind may still work well, but certain physical activities can be harder.

Title: Body cooling between two bouts of exercise in the heat enhances subsequent performance.
Demographic: recreationally active adults (3 women, 12 men), average age 28 years
summary: Cooling off with cold water between two runs in the heat helped people recover and perform better in the second run. This suggests that cold water immersion might be a simple way to boost endurance and help athletes perform better after working out in hot conditions.

Title: Warming by immersion or exercise affects initial cooling rate during subsequent cold water immersion.
summary: This study tested if exercising or warming up before going into cold water would help or hurt. Surprisingly, both types of warming—especially using a hot bath—caused people to cool down faster and could put them at more risk of hypothermia if they later enter cold water.

Title: Heat balance precedes stabilization of body temperatures during cold water immersion.
summary: Researchers immersed six healthy men in cool water for up to ten hours and found that heat balance in the body was achieved before core body temperature fully stabilized. The study helps explain how the body manages temperature during long periods of cold-water exposure but does not show notable benefits or risks for health.

Title: Cooling improves the writing performance of patients with writer's cramp.
summary: Immersing the hand and forearm in cold water temporarily helped people with writer's cramp write better, hinting at a simple, low-cost relief strategy for this condition.

Title: Human physiological responses to immersion into water of different temperatures.
summary: This research explored how immersing young men in water of different temperatures—especially cold—impacts their hormones, metabolism, and cardiovascular responses. Cold water led to clear effects like a big jump in metabolic rate and nervous system activity, but didn't raise the main 'stress hormone' cortisol. The study helps clarify how our bodies respond to cold water immersion, highlighting increased sympathetic nervous system activity but not a simple increase in stress hormones.

Title: Haemodynamic responses and changes of haemostatic risk factors in cold-adapted humans.
summary: After 90 days of daily whole-body cold water immersion, people showed better blood markers for heart health and lower blood pressure, although there was a small increase in another blood clotting factor. This suggests regular cold water immersion may help some aspects of heart and blood health, but also highlights the importance of monitoring possible risks.

Title: Immune changes in humans during cold exposure: effects of prior heating and exercise.
summary: Cold exposure, especially after exercising in cool water, ramped up several aspects of the body's immune response in young men. This suggests that cold water immersion may temporarily stimulate certain immune functions, which could be beneficial for immune health. However, because only men were included, it's unclear whether these findings apply to everyone.

Title: Effects of cold water immersion on the symptoms of exercise-induced muscle damage.
summary: Cold water immersion after strenuous exercise helped reduce muscle stiffness and lower biological markers of muscle damage in young women. However, it didn't seem to reduce soreness or prevent temporary loss of muscle strength.

Title: Cerebral autoregulation during whole-body hypothermia and hyperthermia stimulus.
summary: This study looked at how immersing healthy adults in cold water affects blood flow regulation in the brain. It found that cold water made the brain's blood flow respond more slowly to changes, but it's unclear if this has any good or bad effects for health. More research is needed to know if this has practical benefits or risks related to cold water immersion.

Title: Temperature dependence of habituation of the initial responses to cold-water immersion.
summary: This study suggests that repeated immersion in cool water helps the body adapt, making the initial shock responses (like rapid breathing and heart rate) less intense even in colder water. This could have important implications for cold water safety and training.

Title: Changes in thermal homeostasis in humans due to repeated cold water immersions.
summary: This study looked at how repeated cold water immersions affect the body's response to cold in young male athletes. The main changes included less shivering, feeling less cold, and greater energy conservation, but these adaptations didn’t affect sports performance—suggesting cold acclimation mainly changes how the body manages cold, rather than boosting fitness or causing harm.

Title: Change in sympathetic activity, cardiovascular functions and plasma hormone concentrations due to cold water immersion in men.
summary: This study checked if regular cold water immersion could help the body adapt by changing stress hormone levels or heart function in young male athletes. While a one-time dip triggered short-term stress responses and some tightening of blood vessels, repeated cold exposure didn’t bring about lasting physiological changes.

Title: Isolated effects of peripheral arm and central body cooling on arm performance.
summary: Immersing the arm or the whole body in cold water caused a major drop in arm, hand, and finger function, suggesting that local cooling from cold water is the main reason for declines in performance. This means cold water immersion can significantly impair your ability to do tasks with your hands and arms.
